Add double-sided flag to SpriteBase3D (fixes #8007)

data.title: ScriptEditor: Fixes bug where menu option would be handled twice
data.body: For example, if the current selected tab was a script and the next one a help view, closing the script either via _File -> Close_ or <kbd>Ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>W</kbd> would close both the script and the help view.

data.title: [GDNative] Cannot instance GDNativeScript using `new`
data.body:
Godot 3.0 pre-alpha master
Windows 10 64 bits MSVC

I am making an `opensimplex` GDNative plugin that registers a `Noise` class inheriting Reference (not a node script, unlike the news shows). 
So I compiled my library as a `.dll` using the C++ kit, and put it in the project with GDNaive libraries as well.

Then I created these resources:
`opensimplex.tres`, which references my `.dll` (and other platforms in the future),
`noise.gdn`, which is a resource referencing the `Noise` class within my library.

However, the following didn't work:

```gdscript
const OsnNoise = preload("res://addons/zylann.opensimplex/noise.gdn")

func _ready():
	var noise = OsnNoise.new()
```
`Invalid call. Nonexistent function 'new' in base 'GDNativeScript'.`

@karroffel told me the `new` method might indeed be missing.

-----------------
**The following is wrong due to earlier confusion based on a wrong guess.**

However, I got confused when I went to create an instance of my class in GDScript. Apparently, as @karroffel told me, the `.gdn` already is an instance of the `Noise` class. So getting the instance looks like this:

```gdscript
var noise = load("noise.gdn")
```
But there are numerous things I find wrong with it:

1) It is inconsistent compared to how GDScript classes usually work. From my experience using GDScript, a `.gd` file behaves as a `Resource` containing a *class*, not an *instance*. So instancing it actually look like this:
```gdscript
const Klass = preload("klass.gd")
var obj = Klass.new()
```
And if the Klass inherit a `Node`, you should get a node instance with the script on it. Same for Resources I guess.


2) It makes class constants harder to access, because they are usually bound as "static" members of the class. However with this you are forced to get the constant from an instance of the class, instead of the class itself. Again, in GDScript, this is how it looks:
```gdscript
const Klass = preload("klass.gd")
print(Klass.SOME_CONSTANT)
# or
print(Mesh.PRIMITIVE_TRIANGLES)
```

3) Creating an instance from scratch is too complicated, or requires to create a `.gdn` file which would look like a singleton.
Without a file, this is the code required (pure guess, this code actually doesn't work for some reason, although the same process happens in the editor when creating a `.gdn` file. @karroffel tell me if I'm wrong on this one):
```gdscript
var noise = GDNativeScript.new()
noise.library = preload("opensimplex.tres")
noise.script_name = "Noise"
```

What I would expect is for the .gdn file to represent a class, not an instance, and to be able to create instances the following way:

```gdscript
const Noise = preload("noise.gdn")
var noise = Noise.new()
```~~

data.title: [GDNative] `const` functions cannot be registered
data.body:
Godot 3.0 pre-alpha master
Windows 10 64 bits MSVC

When making a GDNative library using the C++ kit, I figured out C++ functions declared as `const` produce compilation errors when used in method bindings. As a result, none can be declared as such (mostly getters, calculations and things that should be guaranteed to be read-only). This is supported when making a module, I expected it to work in GDNative too.

data.title: Feature request: -rigidonly
data.body:
Among other things Godot's scene importer currently supports:

* a `-col` tag that when importing a mesh will also make an accompanying `StaticBody` based on it
* a `-colonly` tag that imports a mesh only as a `StaticBody`, with no visual mesh, and additionally supports Blender's Empty objects for defining collision shapes like spheres, boxes and so on
* a `-rigid` tag that is like the `-col` tag, but makes a `RigidBody`

However, there is no `-rigidonly` counterpart to `-colonly` for `RigidBody` collisions, which wouldn't produce a visual mesh, and would support Blender's Empty shapes.

It would be nice if there was a `-rigidonly` tag. In the meantime, I'm using `-colonly` on my sphere-shaped Blender Empty along with a small post-processing script:

```GDscript
tool
extends EditorScenePostImport

func post_import(scene):
	var sphere = scene.get_node('SphereCollider')
	var newSphere = RigidBody.new()
	newSphere.set_transform(sphere.get_transform())
	sphere.replace_by(newSphere, true)
	return scene
```

data.title: Option to instance a scene from InstancePlaceholder without replacing it
data.body:
InstancePlaceholder helps a lot on the design of complex scenes and sometimes even replaces the use of exported PackedScene variables (also adds a visual value).

The bad thing of InstancePlaceholder is that is restricted to `replace_by_instance`, limiting the use to scenes that can be instanced only once.

Having a way to reuse the InstancePlaceholder nodes (instancing scenes from it without replacing it on the tree) could be of great use on scene design.

data.title: InputEvent Mouse wheel and viewport mouse coordinates
data.body:
Windows 10 pro Version 1703 - build 15063.183 - Godot 2.1.3 stable/official 


When testing/running a scene in a window and attempting to assess the mouse position when handling a MOUSE_BUTTON / BUTTON_WHEEL_xxx event the get_viewport().get_mouse_pos() returns the mouses location in relation to the operating system display size across all displays and not in relation to the game window itself.   Other MOUSE_BUTTON events are working as desired and returning expected values. 

This was working in Godot 2.1.2 stable as expected but after updating to 2.1.3 and testing a current project I discovered this change in behavior.  I am not certain if this is by design or an unexpected behavior, any input would be helpful. 

reproduction steps are:
1. create a new project that runs in a window (default behavior)
2. create a node in any scene.
3. Attach a script
4. set process input to true
5. in the input event function check for mouse button an button wheel input
6. print output of  get_viewport().get_mouse_pos()

Minimal project attached illustrating the issue:

[Debug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/924601/Debug.zip)

data.title: Support for space indentation
data.body:
Adds support for space indentation in the editor.
Adds two new functions to the text editor to convert between tab and space based indentation. 
Ability to convert indentation on save.

It uses the tab size setting to work out what to convert.

closes #1340
and mentioned in #2982

data.title: rng functions always return 0 in godot3
data.body:
Arch Linux, Godot3 (latest master build)

Using any of the random functions in godot3 always returns 0. this is the case with randf(), randi() and rand_range() even if the seed was randomized with randomize() before.

The following code works as expected in Godot 2.1.3 but not in Godot 3:
```
var random_test
func _ready():
	randomize()
	random_test = rand_range(0,100)
	print(random_test)
```

console output in Godot 3 is always: 0

data.title: Inverse Kinematics broken in 2.1.3
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Tested on Win64 and X11-64 with 2.1.3 and 2.1.2

**Issue description:**
Bone/chain construction works as expected. However, when you click on a bone and drag, it just moves a single sprite object around, without affecting the other objects - just as if you had clicked on the sprite rather than the bone. Reverted to 2.1.2, and everything works fine.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Take any scene with an IK chain. Click on a bone in an IK chain and drag it around.

**Link to minimal example project:**
For example, tutorial 7 and up from here:
https://github.com/ndee85/godot_tutorial_series/releases

data.title: Feature request: .= (dot equals) operator.
data.body:
When working with vector functions, you will sometimes encounter situations such as the following:

    some_vector = some_vector.floor()

It would be convenient if there was an operator that would simplify such operations in the same way that the += operator does.

    a = a + 5
    # Simplified...
    a += 5

Something similar could be done with the . operator. For example:

    laser_direction = laser_direction.reflect(normal)
    # Becomes...
    laser_direction.=reflect(normal)

data.title: Added the ability to select files as base when creating scripts
data.body:
I've found this feature very useful while I was working on my game, so I thought I would share it.
I added a new virtual function to ScriptLanguage (can_inherit_from_file) which returns false by default. This has to be overridden for new scripting languages (I did it for GDScript, don't know about VisualScript).
This is how it looks like:

data.title: When set as "render target", viewport blocks input for children nodes
data.body:
Godot 2.1.3
(can be quickly tested with the "3d in 2d" demo)
Set up viewport as render target, add child with script that uses _input or _unhandled_input and try print event - nothing will happen. With "render target" disabled this issue won't appear.

data.title: BPTC and ASTC texture compression support
data.body:
BPTC is a baseline feature of D3D11, so it's pretty widely available on PC now, and consoles support it as well.  ASTC support on PC is limited to Intel, and on mobile is limited to Tegra and Mali, but support for it will likely improve over time.

Regardless, both share a design challenge: They permit size/quality tradeoffs that break the assumption that there is a single optimal VRAM-compressed format for an image.  ASTC does this by having configurable block sizes, and BPTC does this by being higher quality than DXT1 on RGB-only data, but at twice the size (unlike DXT5, which has no quality advantage over DXT1 on RGB).

So, it would make sense to apply a quality option to images exported to VRAM formats in addition to lossy.  For BPTC, this would mean switching to DXT1 for RGB below some threshold.  For ASTC, it would mean using larger block sizes at lower quality.

data.title: External editor improvements and fixes
data.body:
Notable changes:
- Now ScriptLanguages have the option to override the global external editor setting (_This is specially important now that we have more than one language_).
If `ScriptLanguage::open_in_external_editor()` returns `ERR_UNAVAILABLE` (which it does by default), then the global external editor option will be used.
- Added formatting to the external editor execution arguments. Now it's possible to write something like this: `{project} -g {file}:{line}:{col}`.
- `VisualScript::get_member_line()` now can return the line of functions (well, it returns the id of the _Function_ node of the function). I guess there is nothing else we can get a "line" from.

This commit also introduces a few fixes in the process:
- Fixes a bug where `ScriptEditor::script_goto_method()` would not work if the script is not already open in the built-in editor.
- Fixes wrong DEFVAL for `cursor_set_column` and `cursor_set_line` in TextEdit.
- `Script::get_member_line()` now returns -1 (_"found nothing"_) by default.

Thoughts?

data.title: Godot crashes on startup after Windows 10 Creator update
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows 10 Creator Update - Both Godot 2.1.3 and 3.0 Alpha


**Issue description:** My decision to upgrade to Windows 10 Creator was a mistake for sure but I can at least report this issue now. After I updated Windows 10, Godot crashes on the startup immediately, It doesn't even reach the project manager. Unfortunately the console does not print any errors either. Both the stable and the master branch seem to be affected.


**Steps to reproduce:** I am not sure if it happens for everyone but the issue pretty much started after I updated to Windows 10 Creator. I can imagine this is not something anyone wanted to read today...

![yay](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18212852/25065141/ec4c671e-2209-11e7-9e3a-aa4b7ac2993c.png)

data.title: Developing plugin in c++ sometimes make script mandatory, or require godot-code change
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2+

**Issue description:**
Some functions only use script-methods, the equivalent in C++ is missing.
So when developing a plugin in c++ only, 
this requires workarounds like generating a script by code or manipulate godot-code

example:
It is not possible to select a spatial derived object (by raycast) in the spatial editor, if the editor_plugin is done in C++ and the object is not one of the "built-ins".

**Expected**
all builtin-functions avail to scripting, should be avail to c++ too.
for this example:
maybe a virtual method similar to EditorPlugin::create_spatial_gizmo(..) 
which is called prior to "script"-solution.
or even better add a virtual method get_gizmo_type to spatial itself.

**Link to minimal example project:**
some detail to the above example:
workaround 1 (generate script in c++, so this works):
```
Ref<SpatialEditorGizmo> EditorPlugin::create_spatial_gizmo(Spatial *p_spatial) {
	//??
	if (get_script_instance() && get_script_instance()->has_method("create_spatial_gizmo")) {
		return get_script_instance()->call("create_spatial_gizmo", p_spatial);
	}

	return Ref<SpatialEditorGizmo>();
}
```
workaround 2 (edit godot code, my favorite solution):
one could add a virtual function to EditorPlugin and override it in the custom plugin
then call it in create_spatial_gizmo prior to script search.

workaround 3 (worst one, the whole method is unlucky design)
append the custom spatial to the case list of `SpatialEditorGizmos::get_gizmo(Spatial *p_spatial)`

data.title: MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED returns the speed of repositioning the mouse at center.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64-bit (Godot 3.0)

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Setting the mouse mode to MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED the input returns AND the values to return to the center when the actual mouse movement is finished.

**Steps to reproduce:**
func _ready():
	Input.set_mouse_mode(2)

func _input(e):
	if e.type == InputEvent.MOUSE_MOTION:
		var ms = Input.get_last_mouse_speed()
		print(ms) #See the output for the values.

data.title: clang++.exe in MSVC prompt uses MSVC-specific arguments
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10. Godot 2.1.3-stable

**Issue description:**
I am trying to compile for Android at commit d8ae244d51ed157d96346c510baeb637239e3200 and I'm getting:

```
clang++.exe: error: no such file or directory: '/W4'

scons: *** [platform\android\os_android.os] Error 1

clang++.exe: error: no such file or directory: '/W4'

scons: *** [platform\android\godot_android.os] Error 1
scons: building terminated because of errors.
```

full log: https://gist.github.com/ranmaru90/f0a7e94648a20d4013cde7c0216aaa3d

Compiled with Microsoft Visual C++ Compiler 14.0 (amd64). Python 2.7.13, and I have the latest Android SDK and NDK. 

However, it compiled successfully when I switched to TDM-GCC MinGW 64. 

A separate not-sure-if-it's-an-issue: Compiling for Windows using TDM-GCC MinGW 64 works too. However if I run the compiled Godot and switch to the "Script" tab, if I open many scripts at a time, then try to close them all, Godot will crash. This doesn't happen if I compiled with MSVC 14.0.


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Be at commit d8ae244d51ed157d96346c510baeb637239e3200
2. Be on Windows 10, use MSVC 14.0 (amd64).
3. scons platform=android target=release_debug tools=no -j 2 && scons platform=android target=release tools=no -j 2

data.title: Pool*Array instances should be references and not values in GDscript
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**


**Issue description:**
Calling PoolStringArray.push_back() sometimes silently does nothing.


**Steps to reproduce:**

```gdscript
extends Node

class B:
	static func do_something_else(a):
		a.arr.push_back("I'm B")

class A:
	var arr = PoolStringArray()

	func do_something():
		arr.push_back("PRE")
		B.do_something_else(self)
		arr.push_back("POST")
		print(arr)

func _ready():
	var a = A.new()
	a.do_something()
```

outputs [PRE, POST] instead of [PRE, I'm B, POST]

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Apply is_ceiling/is_wall swap fix to 2D move_and_slide
data.body:
This fixes is_ceiling being swapped with is_wall.

Essentially a condition was slightly the wrong way around, though I've gone and added some comments to that area to help understand the code, partially to help myself understand it,and partially in case of future maintainers.

This project (note: Do not press "3D" in the menu, as that is meant for testing another PR.) shows the bug on master.
